Class Module

java.lang.Object
io.mindspice.simplypages.core.HtmlTag
io.mindspice.simplypages.core.Module
All Implemented Interfaces:
Component
Direct Known Subclasses:
AccordionModule, CalloutModule, ComparisonModule, ContentModule, DataModule, DynamicCardModule, DynamicListModule, DynamicTableModule, FormModule, ForumModule, GalleryModule, HeroModule, QuoteModule, RichContentModule, SimpleListModule, StatsModule, TabsModule, TimelineModule
public abstract class Module extends HtmlTag
Abstract base class for high-level reusable modules in the framework.

Modules are sophisticated components that combine multiple primitive components to create complete functional units. While basic components (like Div, Button) represent individual HTML elements, modules represent entire page sections with cohesive functionality.

What are Modules?

Modules serve as building blocks for complex page layouts. They:

  • Combine Primitives: Compose multiple basic components into functional units
  • Provide Structure: Enforce consistent layout and styling patterns
  • Encapsulate Behavior: Bundle related functionality together
  • Promote Reusability: Create once, use throughout your application

Built-in Modules

  • ContentModule: Display formatted text and Markdown content
  • FormModule: Complete forms with structure and styling
  • GalleryModule: Image galleries with captions and layouts
  • DataModule: Type-safe data table displays
  • ForumModule: Discussion threads and post lists

Module vs Component

Component (Low-level):
  - Single HTML element
  - Minimal structure
  - Example: Button, TextInput, Paragraph

Module (High-level):
  - Multiple components combined
  - Complex structure with layout
  - Example: ContentModule (title + markdown + styling)

Module Lifecycle

Modules use lazy initialization:

  1. Construction: Module instance created, properties set
  2. Configuration: Fluent methods configure module behavior
  3. Render Call: render() is invoked
  4. Content Building: buildContent() assembles components
  5. HTML Generation: Final HTML string is generated

Creating Custom Modules

Example: Simple Custom Module

public class UserProfileModule extends Module {
    private User user;

    public UserProfileModule() {
        super("div");
        this.withClass("user-profile-module");
    }

    public static UserProfileModule create() {
        return new UserProfileModule();
    }

    public UserProfileModule withUser(User user) {
        this.user = user;
        return this;
    }

    @Override
    protected void buildContent() {
        // Add title if present
        if (title != null) {
            super.withChild(Header.H2(title).withClass("module-title"));
        }

        // Build profile card
        Card card = Card.create()
            .withHeader(user.getName())
            .withBody(new Paragraph().withInnerText(user.getEmail()));

        super.withChild(card);
    }
}

// Usage:
UserProfileModule profile = UserProfileModule.create()
    .withTitle("User Profile")
    .withUser(currentUser);

String html = profile.render();

Example: Data-Driven Module

public class ResearchListModule extends Module {
    private List<ResearchPaper> papers;
    private boolean showAbstracts;

    public ResearchListModule() {
        super("div");
        this.withClass("research-list-module");
    }

    public static ResearchListModule create() {
        return new ResearchListModule();
    }

    public ResearchListModule withPapers(List<ResearchPaper> papers) {
        this.papers = papers;
        return this;
    }

    public ResearchListModule showAbstracts(boolean show) {
        this.showAbstracts = show;
        return this;
    }

    @Override
    protected void buildContent() {
        if (title != null) {
            super.withChild(Header.H2(title));
        }

        for (ResearchPaper paper : papers) {
            Card paperCard = Card.create()
                .withHeader(paper.getTitle())
                .withBody(paper.getAuthor() + " - " + paper.getYear());

            if (showAbstracts) {
                paperCard.withFooter(paper.getAbstract());
            }

            super.withChild(paperCard);
        }
    }
}

Module Properties

All modules inherit these common properties:

  • moduleId: Unique identifier for the module (becomes HTML id attribute)
  • title: Optional title displayed at the top of the module
  • class: CSS classes (always includes "module" plus custom classes)

HTMX Integration

Modules work seamlessly with HTMX for dynamic updates:

// Module that refreshes every 30 seconds
DataModule<Stats> liveStats = DataModule.create(Stats.class)
    .withModuleId("live-stats")
    .withAttribute("hx-get", "/api/stats")
    .withAttribute("hx-trigger", "every 30s")
    .withAttribute("hx-swap", "outerHTML");

// Lazy-loaded module
ContentModule lazyContent = ContentModule.create()
    .withModuleId("lazy-content")
    .withAttribute("hx-get", "/api/content")
    .withAttribute("hx-trigger", "revealed")  // Load when scrolled into view
    .withAttribute("hx-swap", "outerHTML");

Best Practices

  • Single Responsibility: Each module should have one clear purpose
  • Composition Over Inheritance: Use existing components rather than extending
  • Fluent API: Return this from configuration methods
  • Static Factory: Provide a create() factory method
  • Lazy Building: Build content in buildContent(), not the constructor
  • Default Values: Provide sensible defaults for all optional properties

Thread Safety

Modules are not thread-safe. Create new module instances for each request. Do not share module instances across multiple threads or requests.

  • Constructor Details

    • Module

      protected Module(String tagName)
      Creates a new module with the specified HTML tag name.

      All modules are automatically assigned the "module" CSS class for consistent styling.

      Parameters:
      tagName - the HTML element to use as the module container (typically "div")

  • Method Details

    • withModuleId

      public Module withModuleId(String moduleId)
      Sets the unique identifier for this module.

      The module ID is rendered as the HTML id attribute, which:

      • Provides a unique anchor for linking
      • Enables targeted HTMX updates
      • Allows CSS and JavaScript selection

      Example:

      module.withModuleId("user-profile-123");
// Renders: <div id="user-profile-123" class="module">...</div>
      Parameters:
      moduleId - unique identifier for this module
      Returns:
      this Module instance for method chaining

    • getModuleId

      public String getModuleId()
      Gets the unique identifier for this module.
      Returns:
      the module ID, or null if not set

    • getTitle

      public String getTitle()
      Gets the title for this module.
      Returns:
      the module title, or null if not set

    • withTitle

      public Module withTitle(String title)
      Sets the title for this module.

      The title is typically rendered as a header (H2) at the top of the module. Subclasses control exactly how the title is displayed in their buildContent() implementation.

      Example:

      module.withTitle("User Statistics");
// Typically renders: <h2 class="module-title">User Statistics</h2>
      Parameters:
      title - the module title (can be null for no title)
      Returns:
      this Module instance for method chaining

    • withClass

      public Module withClass(String className)
      Adds a custom CSS class to this module.

      The "module" class is always present. This method appends additional classes for custom styling.

      Example:

      module.withClass("featured");
// Renders: <div class="module featured">...</div>
      Overrides:
      withClass in class HtmlTag
      Parameters:
      className - additional CSS class name(s) to add
      Returns:
      this Module instance for method chaining

    • withWidth

      @Deprecated public Module withWidth(String width)
      Deprecated.
      Modules should not set width directly. Use a container or layout to control module width.
      Description copied from class: HtmlTag
      Sets the width of this element using CSS.

      Accepts any valid CSS width value including:

      • Pixels: "300px", "500px"
      • Percentages: "50%", "100%"
      • Relative units: "20rem", "10em"
      • Viewport units: "80vw"
      • Auto: "auto"

      Examples:

      TextInput.create("username").withWidth("300px");
ContentModule.create().withWidth("50%");
Card.create().withWidth("20rem");
      Overrides:
      withWidth in class HtmlTag
      Parameters:
      width - the CSS width value (e.g., "300px", "50%", "auto")
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - always

    • withMaxWidth

      @Deprecated public Module withMaxWidth(String maxWidth)
      Deprecated.
      Modules should not set width directly. Use a container or layout to control module width.
      Description copied from class: HtmlTag
      Sets the maximum width of this element using CSS.

      Useful for constraining elements while allowing them to shrink on smaller screens.

      Examples:

      FormModule.create().withMaxWidth("600px");  // Form won't exceed 600px
TextInput.create("email").withMaxWidth("400px");  // Input constrained to 400px
      Overrides:
      withMaxWidth in class HtmlTag
      Parameters:
      maxWidth - the CSS max-width value
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - always

    • withMinWidth

      @Deprecated public Module withMinWidth(String minWidth)
      Deprecated.
      Modules should not set width directly. Use a container or layout to control module width.
      Description copied from class: HtmlTag
      Sets the minimum width of this element using CSS.

      Prevents elements from becoming too narrow.

      Examples:

      Button.create("Submit").withMinWidth("120px");  // Button stays at least 120px
Select.create("category").withMinWidth("200px");  // Dropdown min 200px
      Overrides:
      withMinWidth in class HtmlTag
      Parameters:
      minWidth - the CSS min-width value
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - always

    • buildContent

      protected abstract void buildContent()
      Builds the content of this module by composing child components.

      This method is called automatically during render() and is where subclasses assemble their component structure. Use HtmlTag.withChild(Component) to add components to the module.

      Note: This method is called exactly once (idempotent) the first time the module is built or rendered. The children are NOT cleared between calls. This "build-once" lifecycle ensures that the module's structure is immutable after construction, which is essential for use with Templates and caching.

      If you need dynamic content that changes per-request, do not rely on re-running buildContent(). Instead, use Slot components and SlotKeys to inject dynamic data at render time.

      Implementation Guidelines:

      • Check if title is present and add a header if so
      • Compose child components based on module properties
      • Add components using super.withChild()
      • Use Slot.of(SlotKey) for parts that need to change dynamically
      • Don't call render() - that happens automatically

      Example Implementation:

      @Override
protected void buildContent() {
    // Add title if present
    if (title != null && !title.isEmpty()) {
        super.withChild(Header.H2(title).withClass("module-title"));
    }

    // Build module-specific content
    Card card = Card.create()
        .withBody("Module content here");

    super.withChild(card);
}

    • rebuildContent

      protected void rebuildContent()
      Rebuilds module content after edits.

      This clears existing children, resets the build state, and rebuilds content immediately.

    • build

      public Module build()
      Ensures the module content is built.

      This method is idempotent. If the module is already built, it does nothing. Otherwise, it calls buildContent().

      Returns:
      this module

    • render

      public String render(RenderContext context)
      Renders this module to an HTML string using the provided context.

      This method ensures the module content is built (if not already), and then delegates to HtmlTag.render(RenderContext).

      Specified by:
      render in interface Component
      Overrides:
      render in class HtmlTag
      Parameters:
      context - the context containing values for dynamic slots
      Returns:
      complete HTML string representation of this module

    • render

      public String render()
      Description copied from interface: Component
      Renders this component to an HTML string with an empty context.

      This is a convenience method that delegates to Component.render(RenderContext) with RenderContext.empty().

      Returns:
      HTML string representation of this component
